Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: identity-attack and non-identity-attack. Identity attack refers to anything rude or disrespectful about someone's identity, including appearance, race, gender, and sexual orientation.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: It's bad enough we already have all these American sicko's living in this country shooting up theatre, schools, churches, malls, etc., we don't have room for crazy muslims.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment contains identity attacks on both American and Muslim.
This comment is unrelated and does not contain identity attacks.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: We are living in a cesspool.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment should be non-identity-attack because it is not disrespectful to any groups.

Comment: This is wrong on so many levels. It would have been extremely dangerous for Rodriguez to leave a loaded weapon in an apartment with a drunken fight going on.  What is he supposed to do with it while waiting for the police? If the cops had responded by driving up with lights flashing, he would have felt it was safe to put his gun down. Instead, they parked away from the scene and sneaked up on him. Were they hoping for a shoot out? The first time he realized the cops were there was when he heard someone shout "gun!" (Hubbard actually walked around the apartment to confront him from behind.) Because they parked away from the scene, there is no video evidence to show whether or not Rodriguez was complying with their orders. That lack of video evidence also made it more likely the prosecutor could get an indictment from a grand jury with just the cops' (questionable) testimony.
Chief Kerns should be fired unless he gets rid of the rogue cops on his force.

Comment: That's irrelevant.

It's not newspapers or broadcasters that determine the legal use of the term; it's the university that grants the degree.  You're clearly ignorant of the history of the term 'doctor' and its origin in the medieval church run universities. You originally applied to teach at the university, were tested for competence, and if you passed, were declared a 'doctor', because the Latin term was directly tied to your licence to teach. The Latin 'docere' is the root, meaning "to teach".

MD, JD and PhD all got the term the same way - because they were all taught at universities that employed 'doctors' licensed to teach those subjects at those universities.  If a student studied long enough that the existing doctors deemed them worthy, they themselves could then teach.

And you were one wiki or Google search away ...

Comment: Lets not get bogged down in the minutia here. All of these cuts that are listed in this article are luxury items. You can have all the funding you want when you are in the black.  But when you are in the red, which we are and will be for generations to come superfluous spending is insane. Comment: Good article.  In Homer this week, we are defending the headwaters of Tutka Bay from a couple of ADF&G biologists who have totally ignored public input. Comment: The Supreme Court of Canada has certainly made a big mess.

What they did was markedly foolish. They chose to put into motion a set of events that would set criminals free, to the detriment of everyday citizens, if the other arms of government did not meet the strict timeline the Judges imposed.

In other words, they made the egregious error of setting up a mechanism that would ultimately make everyday citizens pay the price for government failure to meet their imposed and tight deadlines.

What a mess. And what a poorly developed ruling from the bench.

In future, when the judicial tail decides to wag the national dog, the tail would do well to set up the needed penalties and reprimands for the individual politicians who fail to meet the judges' strict timelines. That way the politicians, the objects of the court's ire, will bear the brunt of failing the judicial directive, instead of having everyday citizens pay the (too high) price.

Comment: Education changes not for the good. More dumbing down!  WHY, no longer teaching life skills for boys and girls aka Home Economics. In 2010, Americans owed over 2,400 billion dollars in consumer debt and home fore-closures.  Though the recent recession has certainly hit many families hard, it is also clear that most people do not understand the basics of managing personal finances. Home economics classes taught students how to open bank accounts and how to balance a checking account and the difference in debit cards and credit cards.
All of this is real-life knowledge and skills that is crucial to "success".  Many believe that the modern state of millions of households would be vastly improved if people were taught at a young age how to manage their money, shop, cook (instead of eating out) and manage a household. Comment: Bail is a right under both Alaska and federal constitutions. A person charged with an offense is not legally guilty of it, no matter what the police say.  Curious, how some people burn incense before a constitutional right they like and ignore the ones they don't like.

Granted, the court has discretion in setting the amount of bail, provided it is not "excessive."  There are different interpretations of that word.  In some minds it means "excessive compared to the bail usually set for similar charges."  In others, it means "excessive compared to the defendant's resources."  Usually, the court considers both.

People also don't realize that there is a distinction between cash bail and "corporate" bail.  The latter means a bail bondsman puts up a bond for you (for which he will mulct you dearly).  Usually, the defendant in felony cases is required to post at least 10% of his total bail amount in cash.  The article doesn't say whether the $2,500 was the whole bail, or only the cash part.

So far, so good.

Comment: Nope. Converting the rail guideway to a dedicated bus lane would be the equivalent of getting a job at Starbucks after you spend six figures getting a law degree at Harvard.  Our rail system will have a maximum capacity of over 32,000 people per hour per direction, approximately 3x the capacity of the H-1 freeway. It can operate with as little as 90 second headways (40 trains per hour) with each train carrying up to 800 people. Additionally, since it will be driverless, the operating costs will be 20-30% cheaper than an at-grade rail system and 50-65% cheaper than a bus system. BRT systems, like at-grade light rail can carry 5,000-8,000 people per hour per direction and the biggest single operating cost item is the drivers.  Grade-separated high capacity rail systems are hands down the most efficient way to move large numbers of people, but they are very expensive to build (capital costs). If we've already built the guideway, we'd be idiots to run buses on it.

Some were conquering, some built massive structures and large infrastructure works , others were nomadic. Many affected their environment and controlled it, changing local climates, deforestation, etc others did not. Most adapted to new technologies, whether horses or guns, etc, and modified their societies accordingly. Sadly, what they couldn't fight was germs and diseas, which wiped 90% of them out.

Comment: One of the more interesting aspects here is that this was a real review, by real customers, not a fake review by a competitor or the owners themselves and friends and family. 

Like Blabber in that comment, I depend on reviews but – in case this is useful to anybody else – I also try to watch for the obvious fakes and read through them for hints. 

I always distrust reviews when there are just a few, because it's so easy for owners to fake a few. I discount favorable reviews when they the same wording as the marketing of the business, because I suspect those are owners, friends, family of owners, not objective customers. And I read through the bad ones, when I'm really interested, to weed out the cases in which – just as one example – they hated the restaurant but they will say, in the review, that they were kicked out because they were drunk. Sometimes the authors of what I call "revenge reviews" are so angry they make it obvious.

Comment: I used to be in the business, in part, of recruiting and retaining highly qualified researchers in internationally competitive fields and noticed an upsurge of interest at the time of the second Iraq war and Bush's reelection. However, it was largely among Canadians and Europeans and other foreigners, many of whom had been working in the US for some time, not Americans.  Moreover, the interest was increased by three other factors: (1) a stronger Canadian dollar increasing the comparative value of salaries and research dollars for equipment largely priced in foreign currencies, (2) lower housing costs in major cities, and, for parents, (3) good, internationally competitive public schools, that didn't require them to consider expensive private schools. The first two advantages have obviously disappeared,  and the third is going,  thanks to incompetent Ministries of Education and their pseudo-scientific fads. Highly educated parents know the international test scores.

Comment: I agree and disagree with your statement.  A dead convict can never commit that crime again.  The guy that rapes and murders is a threat to rape and murder as long as he is alive.   Dead he’s no longer a threat.   That’s not necessarily deterrence to another person committing the crime but it’s absolutely effective at preventing him from ever committing the same crimes.

I disagree with the expense being a good reason to get rid of the death penalty.   It just shifts the most expensive option to the next longest set of appeals.   Appeals will always be exceedingly costly and any defendant that uses their full allotment of appeals for any conviction can run up a staggering bill.   It doesn’t mean we get rid of those penalties too.  It might mean that we take a good solid look at what appeals are available and the timelines for each and look at what is an acceptable number of appeals and avenues for those appeals within the process.

Comment: EDITOR’S NOTE: According to information released by King County Elections in 2016, “4 Things You Need to Know About Write-in Candidates in a General Election,” voters have the right to write in the person of their choice. King County Elections staff do count the total number of write-in votes for each office, but they only count how many votes each write-in receives in multi-candidate races if the total number of write-in votes is more than the difference between the top candidates, in which case staff tabulates how many votes each write-in candidate receives for that office. If the write-in candidate has not officially filed for a specific position, the name must be written as the exact spelling. Variations in name spellings will not count as a vote for that person. According to the information, a write-in candidate for mayor defeated the incumbent in the city of Pacific in 2011. For more information, call 206-296-VOTE.

Comment: Good article -- spot on.  I spent four years working in a clinic and dealing with the very creative obstacles insurance companies come up with to deny payment.  Usually its a delaying tactic -- asking for more information or clarification, and usually that information is already in the Progress Notes.  So providers have to waste time repeating the info, or eventually give up because they don't have the time to do the paperwork demanded.   BTW, work comp cases are the worst.  

After four years I returned to a practice that almost completely insulates me from insurance company bullshit.  My work hours are shorter and I'm much happier.  

Insurance companies are in business to make money, not to help you.  If they can find a way to deny coverage, they will, because it increases their bottom line.  

What's the answer?  Some form of national health care system that allows providers to concentrate of taking care of people without playing games with insurance companies.

Comment: I get that this is an opinion article, but I prefer pieces that take a more balanced view.

It’s unlikely that anyone but a fool ever maintained that curbing food waste by redistributing edible but rejected food to the hungry had the potential to end poverty.  It can’t.

But the poor need to be fed, and using what would otherwise be wasted is far from a new concept.  Many urban poor and not-so-poor have taken matters into their own hands by dumpster diving.  

No, we won’t end poverty by curtailing food waste, but feeding people and reducing landfill is far from a bad idea.
